questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: If everyone thinks you're worthless, then maybe you need to find new people to hang out with.Seriously, the social context in which a person lives is a big influence in selfesteem.Otherwise, you can go round and round trying to understand why you're not worthless, then go back to the same crowd and be knocked down again.There are many inspirational messages you can find in social media.  Maybe read some of the ones which state that no person is worthless, and that everyone has a good purpose to their life.Also, since our culture is so saturated with the belief that if someone doesn't feel good about themselves that this is somehow terrible.Bad feelings are part of living.  They are the motivation to remove ourselves from situations and relationships which do us more harm than good.Bad feelings do feel terrible.   Your feeling of worthlessness may be good in the sense of motivating you to find out that you are much better than your feelings today.
dollyAnswerText:
First of all, please seek professional help. It's not healthy to struggle with something like this on your own.

Second, you can start by not focusing on your limitations. Perhaps it's because I'm self-taught but I tend to think that I'm not good at many things. For example, I'm terrible at public speaking, and there's nothing that I can do about it. However, I tend to think that I can't do this, because I can do a lot of other things. The same goes for writing, I'm not good at writing. However, I still think I can still do it. Just keep practicing and you will get better.

Third, try to be grateful. There are many things in life that you can't control, such as death. There's something called 'the law of attrition'. Roughly put, it's the idea that if you keep doing something over and over again, eventually it will become easy. For example, going to the gym regularly will be hard, but eventually it will become a habit. This article fromlifehacker.com may be helpful: https://www.lifehacker.com.au/2017/04/the-law-of-attrition-

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Robin Landwehr, DBH, LPCC, NCCMental Health in a Primary Care Setting
answerText: Hello, and thank you for your question and seeking advice on this. Feelings of worthlessness is unfortunately common. In fact, most people, if not all, have felt this to some degree at some point in their life. You are not alone. Changing our feelings is like changing our thoughts  it's hard to do. Our minds are so amazing that the minute you change your thought another one can be right there to take it's place. Without your permission, another thought can just pop in there. The new thought may feel worse than the last one! My guess is that you have tried several things to improve this on your own even before reaching out on here. People often try thinking positive thoughts, debating with their thoughts, or simply telling themselves that they need to "snap out of it"  which is also a thought that carries some selfcriticism. Some people try a different approach, and there are counselors out there that can help you with this. The idea is that instead of trying to change the thoughts, you change how you respond to them. You learn skills that allow you to manage difficult thoughts and feelings differently so they don't have the same impact on you that they do right now. For some people, they actually DO begin to experience less hurtful thoughts once they learn how to manage the ones they have differently. Acceptance and Commitment Therapy may be a good choice for you. There is information online and even selfhelp books that you can use to teach you the skills that I mentioned. Because they are skills, they require practice, but many people have found great relief and an enriched life by learning them. As for suicidal thoughts, I am very glad to read that this has not happened to you. Still, you should watch out for this because it can be a sign of a worsening depression. If you begin to think about this, it is important to reach out to a support system right away. The National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is 18002738255. The text line is #741741. I hope some other colleagues will provide you more suggestions. Be well...Robin Landwehr, DBH, LPCC
dollyAnswerText:
First,  you need to find someone who will listen to you and validate your feelings and thoughts.  Someone who you feel safe sharing your feelings with and who is not related to you.  A family member, friend or therapist can help with this step.

Next,  pray.  Ask for divine intervention.  Become a victim of your own circumstances and circumstances around you.  Find a trusted and effective clergy member to lead you in a prayerful and concrete request for a solution to help you find peace within yourself.  Follow the steps in the prayer, being sure to focus on your request and pray for guidance and peace.  Some common prayer words are "Help me" or "intercede for me".

Once you have a plan for how to get out of your current situation and feel a sense of control over your thoughts, take steps to execute your plan.  Begin to execute your plan to get out of your current situation.  You will find yourself executing your plan, feeling much better about your self and your situation.

BONUS: Take a therapeutic hot tub bath.  Relax your body and your mind.  Bathe in your feeling of worthless and the repercussions of everyone else's perceptions

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Lee KingI use an integrative approach to treatment and have an online therapy practice.
answerText: First thing I'd suggest is getting the sleep you need or it will impact how you think and feel. I'd look at finding what is going well in your life and what you can be grateful for. I believe everyone has talents and wants to find their purpose in life. I think you can figure it out with some help.
dollyAnswerText:
The first step is acknowledging that you have these thoughts and feelings. Anxiety and depression are debilitating, it is best to seek professional help. Anticipating this, I will provide the following steps that may help. 
Get plenty of rest. Anxious and depressed thoughts will try and bring you down and interfere with your rest, so by getting enough rest you will be able to clear your head of anxious or depressed thoughts.
Meditate. While probably not for everyone, meditation is generally considered to be good for clearing your head and focusing your thoughts. It is sometimes confused with relaxation, but meditation has more components of focusing on a subject in your mind.
Exercise. Being active is known to release endorphins, which help reduce stress and anxiety. However, some exercise is better than no exercise. Going for a walk, taking the dog for a walk, doing some Yoga. Find what helps you feel better and do it.
Love yourself. I know this seems like common sense, but love yourself is important, it actually releases feel like endorphins. Also, give yourself rewards like a massage or cooking dinner for your efforts. This is especially important during hard work like cooking. Give yourself breaks.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Shauntai Davis-YearginPersonalized, private online counseling for individuals and couples
answerText: Therapy is essential for those that are feeling depressed and worthless. When I work with those that are experiencing concerns related to feeling of depression and issues with self esteem. I generally work with my client to help build coping skills to reduce level of depression and to assist with strengthening  self esteem, by guiding my client with CBT practices. CBT helps with gaining a better awareness of how your thought process influences your belief system, and how your beliefs impact your actions and the outcome of your behaviors.  This process isn’t easy but it helps teach an individual that we don’t always have control over what happens in our lives but we can control how we interpret, feel, and behave. CBT is good for individuals dealing with depression, anxiety, toxic relationships, stress, self esteem, codependency, etc.
dollyAnswerText:
I don't know if you've considered it, but you're not worthless. You're amazing and I think you should continue to do what you love. I know that sounds cheesy, but remember how amazing you were in school? You did your best on your speech and debate team and now you run a Youtube channel where you talk about random stuff. You're good at what you do. Everyone gets tired of hearing the same jokes or watching the same YouTube videos over and over. So, put those skills to use and help people in a way you're good at. You love talking to people and that is your strong point. Chat them up on tinder or facebook messenger and try to meet people! 
I don unfortunately have advice for how to deal with feeling worthless, as I've personally felt this way plenty of times in my life. I personally tell myself that I'm not here to validate others opinions, I'm here to do what is best for me. It is not my place to judge, and I try not to take the BS that is thrown my way. Try to sleep at night. You're getting less than 6 hours a night so if you're getting any sleep at all, that's good. Focus on the positives in life, and try

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Jordan WhiteLicensed Social Worker at Oak Roots Dynamic
answerText: I first want to let you know that you are not alone in your feelings and there is always someone there to help. You can always change your feelings and change your way of thinking by being open to trying to change. You can always make yourself available to learning new things or volunteering so that you can make a purpose for yourself.
dollyAnswerText: Write down all of the things you think and feel are worthless. These can be things like how you look, your weight, your clothes, your house, your family, your job, your car, etc. List all of these in the order in which they feel worthless. Repeat this as many times as it feels appropriate for the feeling. While doing this, ask yourself why you feel this way. For example, if you look at yourself in the mirror and think you're ugly, ask why you think you look ugly. Imagine how you would feel if no one else ever looked at you this way and only you had the power to change how you feel. Repeat this as many times as it feels appropriate. Finally, commit to practicing this every day for at least the rest of your life. You can also create a plan for when you feel like suicide is the best option.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Jennifer GerlachYour Story Matters
answerText: That is intense. Depression is a liar. Sometimes depression places these glasses over our eyes, these dark sunglasses that change how we see things. Depression tells us things like "you're worthless" "no one likes you" "don't worry about doing anything." And it is so easy for us to listen and to be tricked into thinking that just because we feel something means it is true. Please know that even if you are feeling worthless right now, that doesn't mean you are worthless.The first step to working through this is recognizing what is going on. Recognizing when depression is telling you the same story (ie; being worthless) with different words (ie worthless here, worthless there) and making an effort to talk back. While I can not give you a diagnosis of depression, reading what you are going through, it sounds like you might need help to get back on track. Seeing a counselor can open an entirely new option up wherein someone who is not involved in your life can help you without judgement and with an objective perspective. This can do wonders in unwrapping these kinds of thoughts. Wishing you the absolute best!
dollyAnswerText:
I'll share a personal experience of mine that helped.
I was diagnosed with anxiety and depression when I was 16. I was fortunate to have a great support system around me during that difficult time. It was an emotionally draining experience, but I also learned a lot. I wish I had known about Cognitive Behavioral Therapy earlier. It would have saved me a lot of heartache and hard work.
I am grateful for my support system and all the help I've received throughout the years. I'll be damned if I am going to throw that away because I feel like this human trashcan. 

Instead, I plan to focus on the positives. I have a deep-seated desire to help people in my community. I want to go back to school to become a counselor or to work with youth.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Christina McGrath Fair"Enlightenment is when a wave realizes it is the ocean." -Thich Nhat Hanh
answerText: It sounds like you may be putting yourself last. You wrote that you want to fix your issues but never get around to it. I wonder how you are spending your mental and physical energy. Are you spending time taking care of and doing for others? I also wonder where the thoughts and feelings of being worthless are coming from  are you around people who treat you poorly or are hurtful? Or do you feel it is more of a worry you have but aren't really sure how others feel? It may be helpful to talk to someone about your feelings  a counselor perhaps  to clarify your feelings and move forward from se that are hurting you.
dollyAnswerText: Write down your feelings on a piece of paper. Sit down and think about each feeling. Repeat the feeling as many times as it is written down. Then replace the word with another feeling. Once you are finished, throw the paper away.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Michael SamarIntegrative Psychotherapist and Mindfulness Coach
answerText: It must be really difficult to experience what your going through right now.  It takes a lot of courage to reach out. It sounds like you want to get better, but perhaps need some help to get over the hump.  Many of the symptoms you have described are consistent with a person who is dealing with depression.   Depression is a treatable condition.  Typically, if these symptoms have persisted for more than two weeks, then it is a good idea to seek professional help.   Someone who is trained in dealing with depression.  Initially, a comprehensive assessment would be completed to rule out any other causes for your symptoms and to determine the exact nature of your presenting concern.  Then, in collaboration with one another, a tailored treatment plan would be developed, focusing on how to best help you reach your goals.  The good news is that their is hope for getting better! You don;t have to do it alone.  Allow me to be your ally in healing.
dollyAnswerText:
- Set time aside for yourself each day
- Do things that make you happy
- Practice mindfulness, so that you can sit with your feelings
- Set goals for yourself

therapistInfo: Michael GreeneTherapy That Focuses on Root Causes
answerText: People who feel worthless were, in one way or another, were told that they are worthless. This is the lie that they are living with. The work of therapy is to help people see their true good selves. This gives them self esteem.
dollyAnswerText: That is a very complex question that not only will require you to look into yourself, but also your surrounding and the society that we live in. I would suggest consulting a therapist and ask them to help guide you through this.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Janna KinnerFlourish Christian Counseling
answerText: I'm sorry to hear you're feeling this intense emotion of worthlessness.  I'm glad to hear this has not reached the point of suicidal ideation; however, it does sounds like you could use some additional support right now.  I would recommend seeking out counseling to help you challenge the negative beliefs you have about yourself.  Although many types of therapy would be helpful, cognitivebehavioral therapy has been shown to be a good approach for this type of struggle.  A CBT therapist can help you identify your negative thoughts and beliefs, figure out the ways your thoughts are being distorted (for example, allornothing thinking, or discounting the positives about yourself), and reframe your thoughts to be more positive.  You might also consider EMDR therapy, which helps the brain reprocess traumatic or distressing memories and helps you move forward with more positive beliefs about yourself.  Best wishes!
dollyAnswerText:
First of all, I wouldn't call yourself worthless. Most people wouldn't consider you that, but it's a subjective opinion.

Next, you can change your perception. Try this to help you think of something else instead of how you feel worthless:

Make a list of all the things you like about yourself.

You can focus on positive qualities or aspects of yourself such as your smarts, ability to make friends easily, your ability to be more calm in difficult situations, etc. Once you think of some qualities, try to focus on those instead of your weaknesses. If you can think of something you like about yourself, focus on that instead of what you dislike about yourself.

It can be easier said than done, but try it and see if you can do it! It's always good to to practice being happy and try to keep that in mind.

Good luck!

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Anna OwensLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: It sounds like you may be struggling with depression. Depression can make you feel overwhelmed and paralyzed to change. I would suggest that you connect with a provider who can help you get to the root of where the worthlessness is coming from and help you develop a plan for recovery. In the meantime, small steps can go a long way. Selfcare interventions such as journaling your feelings, mindfulness meditation, and regular exercise are all helpful to reconnecting with the present moment and gaining internal motivation. Focusing on one day at a time and bringing your thoughts back to the present can also be beneficial. There is hope!
dollyAnswerText: First, try to put your problems into perspective. Think about how you compare to other people. Also try to remember things that make you feel valuable, e.g. your strengths, your hobbies. Remember also that you are not the only person with issues and that others have it much worse than you. Try to imagine that you are not the only one, and try to see other perspectives. This may sound very vague, but it is really the only way to make yourself stop thinking about your problems all the time. It may take time, but try to do this every now and then.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Jeanette Razo-GonzalezLittle Steps Giant Leaps
answerText: I'm glad you are interested in changing your feelings of worthlessness. Visiting your doctor is a great first step to address your lack of sleep. First, you want to make sure that you are physically healthy and that there isn't a physical condition causing your problem with sleep. Changing your feelings is something that is difficult to do, especially on your own. Make sure that you have someone you can trust and you can talk to about how you feel. This can be a friend or a family member. If you find that there isn't anyone you would feel comfortable talking to about this issue, find a therapist close to you who can help. One activity that people have found helpful in feeling better about themselves is keeping a gratitude journal. You can do this by journaling daily about the things that you are grateful for. There is no right or wrong way of doing this, as long as you focus your journal entries on the things you are grateful for in life.
dollyAnswerText:
I want you to know that you are not worthless. It's hard to always be resilient in these situations and sometimes you feel worthless, but you are not.
We have all felt worthless at one point or another in our lives. It's how you respond to that feeling that defines you.
It's important to take deep breaths and remember that you are not powerless over your situation.
It is very likely that if you spend time thinking about how worthless you feel, that will cause your brain to release ENDORPTION HORMONE, which will in turn make you feel better.
Endorphins are natural pain killers and they are produced in your body during and after a painful activity. 
They are usually too soon named "acetaminophen" or "tylenol" after the brand names.
They help regulate your body's pain and discomfort in the short term.
Getting a massage will also help release endorphins and help you feel better.
Trying different activities/dogs/plants to help ease your pain, like trying ground turkey instead of beef to lessen the stress in your colon, or laying on a henna tattoo session, would also help get your mind off of your situation.
Keeping a gratitude

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Bill LeavittOffering you help in dealing with Anxiety, Stress and Depression
answerText:
You have
several things going on here. The sleep should be addressed with a primary care
physician to rule out any physical issues. Sleep is the big reset and allows us
to function in the day. What happens during a depression is that our thoughts
race and it is as though our “brain won’t shut off.” Medication can help with
this. I also use a Pranayama yoga breathing technique called the four
fold breath which has great usefulness for relaxing us  and often does work quite well with allowing
us to sleep.. You can read about it here:    https://billleavitttherapy.com/breathingtechniquesthefourfoldbreath/Your
thoughts on feeling worthless to everyone fall under a heading of thinking
error in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) known as overgeneralization. In CBT
thoughts lead to emotions, so we are going to pick the statement apart and then
reframe it. First list
the evidence that contradicts the thought. Has anyone in the past made positive
comments toward you? This might be hard to recall if we are in a rut, but at
some point in life we frequently have had some positives expressed towards us
by others.  “Everyone” is an absolute. The
specifics on why you are thinking this need to be addressed. How are you
arriving at this conclusion? There may be specific people that we want more
validation from. Or specific people might have made offhand hurtful comments, (such
as a family member, teacher or coworker) but if I extrapolate that to a global
and think that everyone thinks I am worthless, that thought is not rooted in
facts.  
What are
the Pros and Cons of thinking this way? What are the Benefits and Costs? There
are very little pros or benefits to thinking this way. It’s just going to
continue to tear you down and make you feel bad. So can we reframe the thought
about the situation? Is there another way of looking at the situation? Again,
we need the specifics on how you are arriving at this conclusion, and a one on
one therapist can definitely help you with this, but the thinking that you are
using to arrive at the conclusion needs to be recast into a more helpful
mindset.
dollyAnswerText:
Dear loved ones,
You are all extremely valuable to me. It's clear that you've brought out the best in me. I know I can count on you to reach out to me when I'm struggling and to listen to me vent about my feelings. You've also taught me how to trust my instincts and that's huge because I was so wary of being able to rely on myself growing up.
I know I need to get moving and make changes in my life that benefit me. For now, I want to start by taking care of some household chores that are weighing me down.
Thank you for being there for me and learning with me.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Amelia Mora MarsHi, I'm Amelia. I help overwhelmed, stressed out teen girls and women find peace again.
answerText: Hello, you sound like you have so much on your mind! I am relieved to hear that you have never tried or have contemplated suicide, but not being able to sleep, feeling worthless, and like you shouldn't be here are big issues that need addressing.Please get around to counseling.  Having someone to listen to you is a gift to yourself. You deserve the help of someone helping you change your feelings of worthlessness. You have not been able to do this alone. It's time to reach out for help.  You can do this! Best to you!
dollyAnswerText: Consider volunteering or get involved in school or your local community. Being involved in a community helps develop connections and build relationships with people you might not have gotten to know otherwise. The relationships you build during this time will help you later on in life when times get hard. By volunteering your time to a cause or a school that helps others, you will help change your mindset about the people less fortunate than you.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Marie O'Meara, LCSW
answerText: It sounds like you are having some pretty severe depression. Depression can cause insomnia, and make a person focus on their own perceptions that they are "worthless". It is important to remember that other people may not truly perceive you as worthless. This is the depression talking.  I think that it is extremely important when you are this depressed, to sit down and write down some positives about yourself. What are your strengths? What are some positive things that your have done in your life? It concerns me that you are having suicidal thoughts. It sounds like now is the time to act on the idea of getting some help for yourself. If you feel like you might actually take your life, I would recommend that you go to a hospital emergency room, or a mental health crisis clinic right away to get some help. The most important thing right now is to keep yourself safe. If you are feeling like you are not going to hurt yourself despite your suicidal thoughts, I would recommend that you focus on finding a therapist as soon as possible. I don't know what your situation is in terms of insurance. The back of your insurance card should inform you how to obtain mental health services. There are also low cost services available with such places as Catholic Charities, and others. Your local county mental health agency should be able to refer you to some appropriate places. Good luck. Remember to identify your strengths, and the good things about yourself.  Marie
dollyAnswerText:
Just keep on keepin' on! This is something you should feel proud of. Don't let this define who you are, what you can do, and how you treat yourself. You are not worthless, and you can get through anything if you stay positive and stay true to yourself.

It might be hard at first, but you can start by exercising every day. Get a dog or a pet, take a hike or a walk. You will learn a sense of happiness and belonging.

Take a good look at the people that really make you feel worthless. Try to recall who they are, and try to understand their issues. Then try to be like them. Remember the people that helped you the most in your life? Try to be more like them. It might not happen overnight, but keep trying.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Adriana DyurichCOUNSELING, WELLNESS, AND CONSULTING for for Moms, moms to be and their children
answerText: You can, for sure... and the first step is to believe you are worthy TO YOURSELF. Recognizing you are in a quest is already a big first step. Taking the time to start figuring out who you are is definitely the next... do so with SELF COMPASSION and kindness. Know this is a process and just look forward for what you might find.  I do recommend you find someone to talk to (there are many options out there that can fit the situation you are in), and I also recommend you start by giving yourself the importance to invest some time and effort in this quest. YOU DESERVE IT. There are some excellent TED Talks you can google, great books you can read, or even joining a yoga practice, team or some kind of hobby may help. Anything that shows yourself you are worthy of this effort. Have patience and start!!!! the answer is out there waiting for you. Asking these questions already set you on the right path.
dollyAnswerText: Everyone struggles with life's circumstances and I don't expect you to be perfect, but there are things you can control and things you can't control. The first thing you can control is you. You need to make sure you are taking care of yourself. You have to focus on eating and staying hydrated, exercising, meditating and spending time with people that make you feel good. This will help your brain realize that you do exist and that you are not worthless, but just your own unique self.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Heather BradleyHelping you heal from trauma and live meaningful lives
answerText: Oftentimes we can change our feelings about ourselves by building a better relationship with ourself.  It sounds like there is a very critical aspect of your self that is alive and taking over.  Sometimes when we are stuck it is because a part of ourselves, a way that perhaps we learned to cope with difficult situations earlier in our lives, has decided to run the show.  Like a highly critical part that may actually be desperately attempting to protect us from a past hurt. Slowing down and even forming a relationship with this critical internal part will help you get some space from it.  When we can begin to observe parts of ourselves, be curious about them, get to know them like a new friend, then we have room for other ways of being.  Beginning therapy could be a great way to change this feeling of worthlessness.  Beginning to build a better relationship and understanding of yourself will deeply influence the relationships around you.  This first step may feel hard, to reach out to someone, and it could be the beginning step to a path of radically shifting your relationship with yourself and others in your life.
dollyAnswerText: I am sure that everyone experiences low points in life, which is why meditation is really important. Meditation can help you ground yourself in the present moment and focus on the things that you can control.  One of the things you can control is your thoughts. Thoughts, as simple as they may be, can have a big effect on your feelings of worthlessness and can lead you down a path of self-hatred. It is possible to stop yourself from believing these thoughts and even understand that they are completely false and anyone who says otherwise is 100% lying to you. The fact is that everyone is a valuable and loved human being. The feelings of worthlessness you may be experiencing come from an absence of understanding, rather than any deficiency of your own. Meditating and looking at inspiring quotes can really help you shift your perception on things and believe that you are capable of achieving amazing things.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Grace BrooksCaring, Kind and Experienced
answerText: Feelings of worthlessness often originate  from what you learned about yourself when you were young. Improving your self esteem needs focus on that original message from parents, teachers or siblings that may be suppressed.  Most of us need help to uncover the "lie" because you were born valuable!
dollyAnswerText:
Being worthless is a mental health diagnosis that many people suffer with.  Learning what causes this feeling can help to reduce the feeling.  There are 3 main reasons that I've learned cause this feeling: CODA (Coding your life to someone else), ABF (Admitting blame for feelings) and Avoidance (avoiding things that cause feelings of being worthless).  Learning to identify which of these are your issue can be a great first step to getting healthy.  Here are steps to identify what causes your feeling of being worthless:
1)  Understand your coping mechanisms
2)  Understand the CODA and ABF causes
3)  Understand how to reduce the Avoidance
There are many great resources available for learning about these feelings and how to reduce them.  Here are some resources to get you started: 
The CODA model 
https://www.nickbrown.com.au/learn/coding-your-life-to-someone-else.html
Admitting blame for feelings
https://www.nickbrown.com.au/learn/admitting-blame-for-feelings.html
Avoidance
https://www.nickbrown.com.au/learn

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Debbie Gottlieb
answerText: The feeling of being worthless is caused by your inside being not matching your outside result. Your comparison to others and you thinking you need to be someone other than who you are. You are not worthless. No one is worthless. You need to find your worth and not let yourself talk yourself out of the good you find in yourself. I hope these words resonate with you and that you start looking for your worth even if it’s as simple as I am able to get out of bed and call someone and make a joke.
dollyAnswerText:
It's not helpful to just think about this, or write about this in a journal. You have to do something to combat this feeling of being worthless.  You can't keep thinking like this, and that's exactly what you're doing. So the only option is to do something about it.  

The first step towards changing your mindset is to take a step back and realize that you're not in control of everything.  You can only control what you can see, and what you can change.   So next you need to take a look at the things you can see that are causing you to think this way, and change them.  

So you have to understand that everyone is not going to think the way you want them to.  So that you can accept this fact.  So your next steps will be to accept that everyone else is different, and make your own decisions based on this.  Understand that you are not alone, and there are many others who feel this way too.  

I think about this all the time. I wish there was something I could do to stop this feeling.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Minal NebhnaniDiscover Your Best Self!
answerText:
Hi there, I'm sorry you're feeling this way. Let me see if I can guide you in the right direction. Often when I talk to my clients about feelings of worthlessness we start with a little bit of selfexploration. We start with noticing. Start to notice when these feelings come up for you. Is there a particular time
of day, a specific person who brings it out, a phrase you hear? Just
start to notice. Usually it's tied to something but it may take a while to figure out what that something/someone is. Try to be patient.Next we start to explore. When did these feelings start? Where do you think they come from? Is there something  a statement  perhaps that repeats in your head over and over again? If so, whose voice is it? These are difficult questions, and just a few of them, so take your time answering them. (We usually do it over a few sessions.) It might even be helpful to write them down somewhere. If you have a journal that would be a great place as research has shown that our brain works differently when we put pen to paper versus typing on a computer. Now comes the good news. Our brains are able to rewire themselves. This allows us to change habits we don't want as well as statements we say to ourselves that are no longer serving us. The next step is to select an ally. Someone who is or has been in your corner, someone who is always rooting for you. If you don't have someone like that, that's ok  a lot of us don't  you can just make someone up. Close your eyes and try to describe that person in great detail from the way they look to the way they act to the way they sound. Now, pick a phrase you would like that person to say to you whenever you start to think that you're worthless. Something that will help you feel better about yourself  a characteristic, a skill, a great joke you tell, a physical attribute. This also takes time and may involve you asking for help from someone who knows you.Once you have all of that together  the noticing, answers from where these feelings and statement(s) come from, your ally, your new statement, you can try to put it altogether. When the feelings come up, notice what is bringing them up and then call upon your ally to try to change the statement in your head from the selfdefeating one to the more positive, uplifting one. I hope this was helpful. Again, I do this with my clients over quite a few weeks, if not months, and I am there with them the whole time. It is quite an involved process and can bring up a lot of very difficult feeling/memories. If at any point you find it too hard to go at alone, please seek help. If you take anything away from this reply, know that there is help out there and that it is possible to change the way you feel.
dollyAnswerText:
There are a lot of things that you can do to help yourself overcome feelings of worthlessness.

1) Get plenty of rest. Studies show that lack of sleep can cause changes in the levels of certain neurotransmitters, which can increase the likelihood of impulsivity. The brain doesn't need much rest to do its work effectively, so make sure you give yourself enough time to sleep and recharge.

2) Talk to someone who can listen. Being able to talk to someone who can provide non-judgmental and understanding feedback can help. Find someone who's familiar with your situation and who doesn't have a conflict of interest (e.g. a friend who's jealous of your relationship with yourself). You could also talk to a mental health professional (e.g. a therapist).

3) Look for ways to experience pleasant feelings. Find activities that make you feel happy or that allow you to take pleasure in the world around you. Being able to find things to be happy about in your life can help offset negative feelings.

questionTitle: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
questionText:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
therapistInfo: Carmy Howard, LMHC, DCCChange is possible one session at a time
answerText: I am sorry you are feeling this way.  We all have narratives that we say to ourselves whether it is valid or not.  In your case it would be beneficial to explore when and how this belief began and rewrite your story.  There are different ways to explore and rewrite.  This process requires commitment, selfreflection and courage.
dollyAnswerText:
I know it's early in the morning, but I will try my best to answer your question.  How do you start working on yourself?

First, you need to take a step back and breath. Remember, you are not here to fix other people's problems. You can be a helping hand but not a doormat. Remember that. If you see someone falling down, you can help but not step on their hand. Take a step back and examine what is really going on for you. Look at your thoughts, feelings, and overall mindset. Ask for help when you need it, but don't be afraid to take on some of this burden. 

Also, remember that you aren't alone. I know this is hard to believe, but I am here for you if you need me. Remember that people in your life might not be supportive right now, but they are still in it for you, so they care. Ask for their help as well. Someone might be able to distract you or help you find a way out of your feelings. Remember that you don't have to do this all on your own.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Noorayne ChevalierMA, RP, CCC, CCAC, LLP (Michigan)
answerText: Let me start by saying there are never too many concerns that you can bring into counselling. In fact, most people who come to see me for counselling have more than one issue they would like to work on in psychotherapy and most times these are all interconnected. In counselling, we work together, collaboratively, to figure out which issues you would like to address first and then together we develop an individualized plan of care. Basically, it’s like a road map of where you want to go, how are you going to get there, looking at stopovers, some scenic routes others possibly not so scenic, however, necessary. Of course, these plans can also change due to internal (what we have control over like our thoughts, feelings and behaviours) or external reasons (those things that are outside our control). I would encourage you to take the next step and reach out to a professional you can trust and build rapport with by cojourneying through whatever concerns you have by examining what has been working so far as you have learned to cope with some of your issues like insomnia, depression and anxiety, as well as being a breast cancer survivor. Then to help you by developing new coping strategies. Psychotherapy can be such a powerful tool to help you get to where it is you want to be. I know you can do it and you will see firsthand how psychotherapy will help you to move past these points in your life where you are feeling stuck. I like to quote Nike where their motto is, “just do it.” You can do it.
dollyAnswerText: Yes, you do. Too many issues to address!  I can help you address these issues in a safe and healthy manner through counseling. It’s completely normal to have multiple issues that you need to address.  Having an issue doesn’t make you broken. It’s the way you respond to life’s challenges that make you a whole person. I’ll help you to understand your wounds, understand how they have affected you and help you to heal so that you can heal others. We will look at your history, what you’ve gone through, what you expect from therapy and together, we will create a plan for optimal wellness.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Heather BradleyHelping you heal from trauma and live meaningful lives
answerText: It is never too late to get help and begin making significant changes and improvements in your life.  The right time is when you feel ready and open to change.  Sometimes when we have a history of trauma, like sexual abuse, the impact of that trauma can affect many areas of our lives as adults.  Working with a therapist who specializes in trauma is a great way to begin developing skills to manage present day life, learn to regulate your emotions and nervous system when you become triggered, and then in a safe environment have the opportunity to process past traumas so you can live your present life with more ease and joy.  People can and do recover from the impacts of trauma at any stage in their life.  It is never too late and you can feel better
dollyAnswerText: Yes, if you have too many issues for your situation to manage you are likely facing strain in your relationship with your therapist. There is a fine line between addressing all of your issues, and counseling falling short because you won’t show up or don’t understand what you’ve signed up for. If you are struggling with this I recommend reaching out to your therapist for guidance.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Sara Makin, M.S.Ed.,NCC#1 Best Selling Author & Counselor
answerText: You have been through so much and it sounds like you have a lot of things that have complied over the years. Regardless of the struggles you have been through, you do not have too many issues for counseling. Many times when someone starts out their counseling and healing journey, there are multiple things they would like to address and work on. If you decide to start counseling, you and your therapist can decide collaboratively what you would like to process and work on first. Be sure to express to your counselor if any of the above experiences you've been through is causing a lot of distress , as many times the first things addressed are the ones that are presently affecting your life or you emotionally. Often times when we experience negative situations in our life , but do not address them, they bottle up inside us and can manifest in other ways, such as depression or even physical symptoms like IBS or neck pain.  Counseling can give these bottled up emotions and situations a release. Given the situation you shared, not only do I not think that you have too many issues for counseling, but believe that you will be a great candidate and can get a lot from it.
dollyAnswerText: Yes, it sounds as if you have too many issues to address in counseling. In fact, if counseling hasn’t addressed these issues, it may not be the right kind of counseling for you. For example, it sounds as if you’re interested in religious counseling, which is notoriously good at addressing issues of low self-esteem. But it can also be bad at addressing the problem of sexual abuse, since sexual abuse is not the fault of a person’s character, but rather is related to a person’s biology and wiring. Sex abuse counseling may even make you more anxious. On the other hand, if your depression is not being addressed, it might be time to find a different counselor. If your insomnia is not being addressed, it’s also time to find a different counselor. And if you have low self-esteem, you are concerned with the way you look and you have not been to counseling before, it’s time to find a new counselor.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Shakeeta TorresFaith Based Mental Health Counselor
answerText: Absolutely not.  I strongly recommending working on one issue/need at a time.  In therapy you will set smart goals and objectives that will help you reach your goals.  I see you as a survivor and not a victim.  Best wishes to you.
dollyAnswerText: No, you do not have too many issues to address in counseling. Rather, your level of issues may be a reflection of the systemic issues in your life that are contributing to your mental health challenges. It could also be a reflection of your individual traits or characteristics. Regardless, you do not have to address every issue you have in order for counseling to be helpful. Counseling is meant to be a collaborative process. By sharing your experiences and exploring your thoughts and feelings about them with a counselor, you will be starting to build resilience to some of the challenges you face in your life. Some of the skills you will learn in counseling could be helpful in addressing your challenges, such as developing problem solving skills, identifying and expressing emotion, setting limits with people you care about, and building and maintaining deep and meaningful relationships.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Wendy MitaWorry less, live more!
answerText: Absolutely not!  In fact, most people have many issues,  A lot lot of the issues you are describing commonly go hand in hand ( in "therapy speak" we call it comorbid conditions)I would venture that most of the feelings you are struggling with stem from your early trauma.  You would benifit tremendously from counseling!  A good therapist will develope a treatment plan that addresses all of your needs. With help you could definitely live a happy life without all of your anxiety and depression getting in the way!
dollyAnswerText: No, you do not have too many issues to address. The important thing is to focus on those issues that you can control and which are actually hampering your ability to function successfully.   Identifying what those are will provide you with a clear picture of what to work on and what to leave aside.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Danielle JoelCompassionate Mental Health Care
answerText: This is a great question! I personally don't believe that any client could ever have too many issues for counseling. In fact, that type of thinking may be stopping you from seeking counseling, so it may be hindering you from getting the help you need. In fact, all of what you described points to the importance of you seeking help in order to cope with the many challenges in your life. If you seek counseling, it will be important for you to understand that you may need to remain in counseling for a sustained period of time in order to work through each of these issues. All of these issues won't be able to be solved right away or in a brief period of time. Counseling will take commitment and hard work, but it is possible for you to recover and heal from all of the issues you described.Many clients come into counseling with numerous issues rather than just one particular thing. Most of the time, the issues relate to and exacerbate each other. We call these "comorbid" conditions, which means that two or more mental health problems exist at one time. A lot of the times, when you start to work on one issue, the other issues get better as a result.I encourage you to find a professional therapist that can help you learn how to cope with all of the mental health difficulties that you described. You deserve the help just as much as anyone else.
dollyAnswerText:
This may depend on your point of view, but to me the answer is a resounding yes. If I were to list all of my issues, it might sound like a daunting list. And that would be true if you only considered my personal issues. But if you consider the issues that impact my relationships with others, then it becomes much easier to see that I do indeed have too many issues to address in counseling. 

I was raised in a home where my mother suffered from depression and used alcohol and drugs to medicate. As a result of this, I learned that the way I talked to others, the way I carried myself, the way I expressed my emotions and the way I initiated or ended a conversation were all matters of “who I am”. I believed that by simply changing who I was, I could change who I was not getting; I could change how others treated me. And I believed that if I didn’t address these things, then I would never have a healthy relationship. So I began to address the things I could control, changing my tone of voice, my posture and my words. 

After about 10 years, I still was not getting what I wanted. I remember the therapist saying to me, “You must be losing money to

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Olivia ClearHonor your spirit, clarify your vision, align with your purpose.
answerText: Hi! Many people begin their therapeutic journey with histories just like yours and experience transformative shifts in their quality of life.  I hope you are able to find a counselor you feel comfortable working with and do the work if you feel called. Best of luck on your journey!
dollyAnswerText: You do not have too many issues. In fact, it is likely that you do not have enough issues. People who suffer from a myriad of issues, such as you, typically need a wider scope of counseling and not just individual counseling. During therapy, you will likely discuss your childhood experiences that may have left you with an underlying sense of worthlessness, low self esteem and feelings of being not good enough. Additionally, you will likely uncover the various contributors to your current feelings of anxiety and depression. This may include past traumas, relationships, etc. Even when therapy does not fully fix the causes of your issues it is likely that the multiple issues you suffer from become less noticeable due to the overall improvement in your emotional and psychological well being.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Heidi SchnakenbergSpecializing in family relationships specifically adolescents with conduct issues
answerText: Absolutely not. It sounds like you have significant trauma and it will continue to impact your depression until it is dealt with. Everybody has issues, though some more traumatic than others yet it is best to just start somewhere. I would encourage you to begin counseling and work through some of your history at your own pace in order to begin to impact and reduce your depressive symptoms.
dollyAnswerText: Yes, you have too many issues for a single counseling session. Counseling is a process that should take at least 6-8 weeks, ideally longer to address these many issues.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Wendy GagneMarriage Family, Individual Specialty ADHD and ANGER
answerText: Most clients have many issues that need working out. It is normal to have many events in our lives that trouble us and remain with us without counseling help. The right type of counsellor will help you focus on the main and most troubling issue you have first and work your way through all that you are managing step by step, goal by goal. Sometimes, working on  one issue helps to bring other issues to light in the context of your main problem. This can help you resolve some other issues that are connected. Look for someone with experience and specialty in your most pressing issue...even though you have had breast cancer, you may find that grief from your past is more troubling. Then you would look for a bereavement or grief specialist.
dollyAnswerText: You do not have too many issues, but it is important that you feel comfortable in the process. It is very helpful if the counselor has experience with someone with issues similar to your own. This will make the process more comfortable for you, and help you get the most out of your counseling session.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Dr. Melissa ValentinaHonor Yourself and Live Your Truth
answerText: Just go! You start with the most prevalent issue by talking with your therapist. Healing one issue can have a ripple effect and heal other issues as well.
dollyAnswerText: I don’t believe you have too many issues to address in counseling. You must feel as if you have not addressed your issues in the past.  You have to acknowledge that you have issues in your life and that they have been affecting your daily functioning. You have to find a counselor who has experience with people like you and actually cares about helping people like you. Make sure the counselor has a sense of humor. People need to feel that they can speak to you honestly without worrying that the information they share will be considered “strange” by you.  Pace your workouts with the counselor. An exercise can help you focus on the process of addressing your issues rather than avoiding them in your sessions.  Don’t expect to leave your counseling sessions with an immediate sense of closure because often your issues will not have a clear beginning, end or solution. However, give it time and you will find that you have more compassion for yourself.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Kerri ScullyLicensed Professional Counselor
answerText: There is no such thing as too many issues for counseling. Many issues are often interrelated and can all be worked on with some time and patience.
dollyAnswerText: No, you do not have too many issues to address in counseling. In fact, it is very unlikely that you have addressed all of your issues in counseling. If you have not been to counseling, I recommend that you seek counseling. You may find that there is one specific issue that is causing you stress and that you could address together. You might also find that by sharing your feelings with a neutral third party, you may be able to share your emotions more directly with your counselor and gain more insight into your feelings.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Tasha HunterTrauma Therapist in Goldsboro, NC
answerText: Hi, people who have only a few issues and people who have several issues are perfect for therapy. There is no such thing as having too many problems for therapy. Therapy is great because it will help you process all that you are going through, heal from past and present pain, and gain clarity.
dollyAnswerText: The short answer is no, you do not have too many issues to address in counseling.  What you have experienced in your past, and the symptoms you are experiencing now, are completely normal and expected.  What you require now is guidance in addressing some of your past experiences, your high self-esteem, low self-esteem, and how you are currently experiencing sleep disturbances and the symptoms they are causing you.  These issues will affect each of the other issues you’ve experienced in the past, your history of abuse, your history of depression and your history of anxiety.  It is important to understand that the problems in the past are what allowed these problems to occur in the present, therefore understanding these problems in the past and addressing them will alleviate the current suffering.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Dr. Timothy Paul'man'; Online - "Natural Health Consultant and Coach"
answerText: Yeah, you might :)At least, it certainly feels like that, I bet...Not to mention that most counselors out there might generally feel overwhelmed with a "case" with so many problems.  And, so, you will slog along weektoweek with gradual improvements occurring as she slowly does her best to chip away...The real issue is that these folks don't yet comprehend the integrative nature of each of these subjects and how generally simple it is to understand them, and then eradicate them.
dollyAnswerText: Yes, you definitely have too many issues to address with only one counselor. You should seek multiple types of counseling (e.g. Cognitive Behavioral, Mental Health Counseling, Christian Counseling, etc.) to ensure all of your needs are being met.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Leonard PikaardWhen you're ready, help is here.
answerText: It could be said that you might be the perfect candidate for counseling! No one is beyond hope, and someone brave enough to be honest regarding their struggles, with the intention of reaching out for help is certainly a person a qualified counselor would be happy to assist. You may want to do some research on therapists in your local area who specialize in mindbody connection, or one of the struggles you have acknowledged in your post, in order to find a therapist that is best suited to meet your needs. Good luck on your search, and remember that the world is a better place with you in it.
dollyAnswerText:
No, I do not have too many issues to address. All you need to consider when deciding if you should have counseling is:
1. Do you want to address the issues you’ve identified?
2. Do you have a support system of people you can share the issue with?
3. Are you ready to make a commitment to attend counseling?
4. Are you able to pay for counseling?

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Michelle BarnhartPhoenix Rising Counseling
answerText: No, there are never too many issues to address in counseling.  Therapy would begin by prioritizing what you feel needs to be addressed first.  As one area improves, such as processing history of abuse you are likely to see improvement in other areas of your life...like sleeping better.
dollyAnswerText: No, it is not too many issues to address if you have followed this link and researched the different approaches to addressing your issues. You have multiple issues, but not all of them can be addressed with therapy. Some things are beyond the scope of counseling, such as religious issues or legal matters.    Some people have different opinions about how many issues one should have in counseling, but I would encourage you to seek counseling if you feel you need help.    Good luck on tackling all your issues!

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Ivy GrossHelping Individuals Heal and Grow
answerText:
Firstly, I would like to say how amazing that you have been able to live through breast cancer, sexual abuse as well as your depression and anxiety. You are stronger than you may believe at this moment for being able to continue to grow and live through these experiences. Take a moment to acknowledge your strength and know that this strength will be an asset during the therapeutic process that you will be able to tap into to find increased self esteem and more strength to address the concerns you are having. There are never too many concerns to address in therapy sessions. I hope you can find a great therapist who you can trust to listen and work with you to identify and address
the most concerning issues first. Once you begin to do this you may find an alleviation of symptoms and feelings which could allow you to grow your capacity to manage difficult feelings and situations and address additional concerns. Before you even realize it the issues you are having will begin to feel more manageable.
dollyAnswerText: Based on your history, I do not believe you have too many issues to address in counseling. I do not believe you have enough issues to address in counseling. I believe you have too few issues to address in counseling. At present, I would say you have the following issues: depression, anxiety, and low self esteem. These issues could possibly be addressed in a couple of different ways. Some examples of possible treatments are: medication, psychotherapy,  Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, and supportive counseling. It is important to ask your significant other, significant friends, a therapist, and a medical professional whether you should seek any of these types of treatments.  This will help you make an informed decision.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Tanya HernandezHelping you to overcome overwhelm and jump back into life!
answerText: Absolutely not! It is never too much. The most important thing is that you are reaching out to get help.  Therapy helps you to develop healthier coping strategies and that can help reduce the anxiety and depression as well as improve your sleep. This can all be done at a pace that is best for you. Your therapist can help you process all of this in a safe and supportive space.
dollyAnswerText: Yes. It is best to have fewer, bigger issues. If you have too few issues for counseling to address, it is best to find someone else to address them. It may be a good idea to start with a general practitioner or psychiatrist who you think you can work with. It is good to explore whether there is something else going on that can be diagnosed or treated.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Christina McGrath Fair"Enlightenment is when a wave realizes it is the ocean." -Thich Nhat Hanh
answerText: No, it is natural for us to have a number of issues going on if we don't address the concerns we have in our lives. Seeking counseling can assist you in working on these issues individually as well as ways in which they intersect and impact each other.
dollyAnswerText:
I believe you do have too many issues to address in counseling.  As a culture we have become extremely shift focused and materialistic and counselors are expected to have special training in these areas. But the most important reason you have too many issues is that you’re actually experiencing symptoms that result from decades of poor health and poor lifestyle choices that are compounding your long term problems. You cannot adequately address just one issue at a time. 

So I believe you need to address all of your issues in counseling and your chosen counselor must have training in working with individuals who have suffered multiple long term chronic illnesses.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Tracey PoirrierPolaris Counseling & Consulting Services PLLC
answerText: The most direct answer is no. I would venture to guess that several of the things you are feeling (symptoms) are connected. I would recommend a trauma counselor. You have several strengths (resources) that you are able to pull from and I would encourage you to focus on them as you deal with the issues you have placed on the back burner for so long. Sometimes people are afraid to address things because they feel or believe that they won’t be able to handle it. Compare it to a tornado. The storm has passed, but you are still in hiding for fear of the aftermath (the mess left behind). A good therapist is like a personal organizer to help you.
dollyAnswerText: No. By addressing them, you will give yourself a better opportunity to heal and thrive.

questionTitle: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
questionText:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?
therapistInfo: Kelly Freeman, MS, LPC"Change Your Thoughts and you change the World." -Norman Vincent Peale
answerText: It's not really a question of whether you have too many issues for counseling but more what would you like to work on in counseling?
