I am so very sorry that you are going through this. It truly is a painful experience and I wish I had an answer for you. In truth though I don't, I am not a professional counsellor.
I am however a professional software developer, and have gone through things like this personally. And I would like to offer you some guidance and tips that I hope help.
So firstly, try and find a group of friends that are in a similar situation to you, whether it's other people who are currently going through a breakup or people that you hang out with regularly who are already in that situation. Hearing how other people are going through this can be a great source of reassurance.
Secondly, try and make sure you don't do anything drastic, I know it feels like you will run out of time, but try to take things one step at a time and don't be afraid to sit and think about your situation. Writing things down helps me a lot, I will often write out lists of things I need to do to help ease my transition. 
Thirdly, remember that no matter what, you will still be you, and you are in control of how you deal with this. As cliché as this sounds,

questionTitle: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
questionText:
I recently broke up with my boyfriend After being together for over 4 years. I truly believe I did the right thing, but omehow being single now has made me very needy and unsure of myself.
    I am seeing someone casually and I am losing my mind with anxiety about how he feels about me and this need for validation.
   How can I learn to be content and at peace with myself regardless of my career, relationship status, etc?
therapistInfo: Dr. John Frampton
answerText: A break up, even one that you initiated, may deserve some time and space to allow it to be complete.There's a few ideas I'll throw out there and you can choose if they stick.  One is to reinvest in the friendships you have by setting up regular coffee gettogethers for example.  Two, get out in nature.  It's hard to ignore how grand and patient nature is, and it sometimes takes the pressure off what we should be and instead allows us to be.  And the last one I'll throw out there is to invest your time and energy in a project or achievement you've wanted to do for a while, but that perhaps you didn't have the time to.  Something related to a hobby such as sports or music, or related to your career.  Something that is 'for' you.  Life knocks us off balance at times, and that's ok.  Selfquestioning during these times can be a healthy endeavor.  Should you follow any of the advice on this website, continue to be kind to yourself about what you're feeling, and curious about why you're feeling that way.
dollyAnswerText: Do what makes you happy. If your boyfriend does not fill a hole in your life, then do not let your feelings for him get in the way of what makes you happy. You know yourself best and what makes you happy.

questionTitle: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
questionText:
I recently broke up with my boyfriend After being together for over 4 years. I truly believe I did the right thing, but omehow being single now has made me very needy and unsure of myself.
    I am seeing someone casually and I am losing my mind with anxiety about how he feels about me and this need for validation.
   How can I learn to be content and at peace with myself regardless of my career, relationship status, etc?
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Possibly you haven't completed your phase of mourning the recently passed relationship and lifestyle which surrounded it.Relationship breakups mean a person's entire life goes through an adjustment since the relationship impacted all areas of your life.Give yourself some patience to restore yourself from the old relationship. When you feel whole again then more than likely you will lose some of the anxiety wondering what your new casual partner feels about you.And instead of wondering,  you may simply decide to ask the person your question!
dollyAnswerText:
When you were a kid or a younger adult, how did you feel about having a boyfriend or girlfriend? Were you seeking outside validation? Did you seek out status with them?
I suggest you keep that perception in the present and do not seek that validation now from other sources. You want to be content in the present, but also wise about how you react to outside influences or dopamine hits.
As you age you find you don't need that same validation from someone outside of yourself. You will develop friendships and relationships that provide that validation, just as you grew up learning from your parents or in school from your teachers.
With a new relationship, you will feel lost for awhile because your emotional needs are not met from a relationship. In order to feel that you need to seek that validation from others as well. If the relationship ends that validation will not be there. It is better if you seek it out from outside sources because there are those that the relationship might create. They might tell you that you are a good friend or they might give you material things that you seek that validation from. This can lead to more excitement and therefore more dopamine hits. But at the same time it can lead to you making life decisions based on these dopamine hits and not on a true assessment

questionTitle: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
questionText: I'm a teenager, and while I’ve never been to any kind of therapist, I noticed I experience several anxiety symptoms. I frequently find myself not going out and following my parent around the house. I can't go into stores (grocery stores specifically) on my own, and when I do, I have to be on the phone with my dad the whole time. I also forget things a lot.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Despite your anxiety you are highly attuned to your sense of well being and skillful in articulating the details of when anxiety takes over.Sometimes people who anxious in specific realtime situations are helped by talking themselves through the anxiety.Maybe you'd be able to distract yourself from the grocery store anxiety by telling yourself you're anxious and that you'll be ok, its only a grocery store.The longer term way to dissolve anxiety is through selfacceptance, selflove, selfbelief, basically all the areas of trusting yourself to handle situations.Anxiety is a fear of being overwhelmed by a circumstance or condition which ends badly for you.Often the person can very well handle the situation about which they're anxious.   The problem is not trusting themselves enough to rely on their self knowledge.
dollyAnswerText: Hi there, and thank you for using our service! I'm so happy to help! It sounds like you have experienced many anxiety symptoms. It's great that you noticed them and were able to get help quickly! It can be so helpful to have someone hold you accountable, such as a parent, but remember that you are not alone. I encourage you to seek out a therapist who can help with cognitive behavior therapy (CBT), which helps you identify and challenge negative thoughts, which can cause anxiety symptoms. It can be so helpful to schedule a session to talk through your anxieties and develop a plan for tackling them, such as having someone on your cellphone, but it's also ok to schedule a one-time 15 min session via text. Again, know that you are not alone, and feel free to reach out to me again should you have more questions.

questionTitle: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
questionText: I'm a teenager, and while I’ve never been to any kind of therapist, I noticed I experience several anxiety symptoms. I frequently find myself not going out and following my parent around the house. I can't go into stores (grocery stores specifically) on my own, and when I do, I have to be on the phone with my dad the whole time. I also forget things a lot.
therapistInfo: Lauren Ostrowski, MA, LPC, NCC, DCC, CCTPI tailor my therapeutic approach to each client's strengths and goals
answerText: With the way you described your anxiety, it sounds like you have different types of anxiety. I'm not sure whether you have anxiety of public places, large crowds, being alone  (sometimes called separation anxiety), or some combination thereof.One thing that would be helpful would be to track your anxiety and see how anxious you are (on a scale of 1 to 10) in different situations. Also, if you know what leads up to your anxiety, it would be good to know this as well so you can look for patterns.As for forgetting things, you could be anxious because you are forgetting things or you could be forgetting things because you are anxious. When you are having anxiety, certain parts of your brain are overactive because you are in a kind of protective mode. It's also possible that forgetting things and anxiety are not related.Something else to try would be to notice where you feel your anxiety in your body and put your hand there is a way of giving yourself comfort.Another thing about anxiety is that having anxiety can lead to more worry about having more anxiety. One thing that helps for some people is to go to the regular primary care doctor to make sure that there are no physical problems (just for the regular physical) so they know that there are no physical problems and that the anxiety will lessen in a few minutes.Also, if you are able to notice your feet on the floor or your hips in the chair, this is helping you to be mindful of your body and connecting you to your surroundings. During this in combination with naming your emotions can be soothing as well. For example, in the grocery store, if you are feeling anxious, you could say to yourself "I'm anxious right now and I'm okay" while gently shifting your weight from one foot to the other. No one around you would notice what you were doing and the motion may be soothing to you.Anxiety can have a lot of different causes and things that trigger it. If it is difficult for you to work it out on your own (which is very common), consider talking with a local therapist so you can have more specific ideas.Also consider making a list of people who you trust and what it is about them that makes you feel comfortable.
dollyAnswerText:
This is an incredibly common experience for teenagers who are dealing with anxiety and depression. It is really important that you seek support from adults who you feel comfortable approaching, such as your parents or a close friend. Teens experiencing these symptoms are often dealing with both anxiety and depression. This is particularly true when they experience symptom such as forgetfulness. It can be challenging to go outside and live your life, but it's even more challenging when you're struggling to keep track of all of your daily responsibilities. It's helpful to talk to someone about your concerns, and it's important to be open to the idea that things might not be completely “cured” right away. I know it feels great to be in charge of your mental health, but sometimes it's actually more beneficial to seek help from those who have more experience in treating mental health conditions than trying to navigate it on your own. Seeking help is more likely to make you feel better than forcing yourself to feel better, and in the long-run, it's likely going to make you healthier as well.

There are numerous resources available to help teenagers struggling with anxiety and depression. Here are a few to look into:
- The American Heart Association offers a ton of information and tips on heart health for teenagers

questionTitle: I have difficulty with communication
questionText: I am a really shy person. I'm currently in a graduate program which requires lots of presentations, but they always make me feel stressed out and less confident. How can I get more confident?
therapistInfo: Frank WalkerI help couples manage the bumpy road called marriage. Whether your marriage needs a tune up, a major overhaul or just a flat tire changed. I can help.
answerText: Wow, congratulations on being in a masters program. You are in a unique place. So few have reached that level. You should give yourself a pat on the back.Confidence is not something that comes naturally. But can and does come with practice.Having gone through two masters programs I can sympathize with your your dilemma. So how is the stress affecting you?Is it serious enough to stop you from presenting or is it just "butterflies"?There are many ways of dealing with the anxiety and stress. Much depends on how serious the stress is.So here are a few ideas:1. Practice in front of a mirror.Sounds strange but the practice helps.2. Ask some friends to listen to your presentations. Not so much for their input as to just get used to presenting.3. Focus on the material you are presenting. The subject matter is what you want to get across. Step away from your nerves and get into the facts you want to present. Let the material you present be the focus. 4. Remember everyone else is just as nervous as you. Share your fears with some of your classmates and gain support from them. Focus on a friendly face during the presentation. Be a support to them in return.5. "Fake it, till you make it". Yes it sounds blunt. But sometimes that's what it takes. Even if you feel like it, you won't die.So much more can be discussed with a competent counselor. Take the time to let a professional help you work through this.Again you have come a long way to be in a graduate program. Congratulations you have done great work so far. It's just one step at a time, take the steps.
dollyAnswerText: One way is to make more presentations. This will help to make you feel more confident because you are spending more time thinking about your presentation, and there is pressure from an audience for you to be successful. Another way to get more confident is to practice your presentation in front of a mirror. That will help you to know how you are coming across to the audience and will make you feel more confident. To help practice in front of a mirror, you can look for examples of good and bad presentation on YouTube, look at the presenter's notes, or even watch someone else do a presentation. Practice makes permanent, so keep doing it.

questionTitle: I have difficulty with communication
questionText: I am a really shy person. I'm currently in a graduate program which requires lots of presentations, but they always make me feel stressed out and less confident. How can I get more confident?
therapistInfo: Amy NolanYour journey to wellness starts here!
answerText: A good way to start is the language or "self talk" that is happening inside your mind.  Looking at your question, when it is said that the presentations "make me feel stress" you are giving the responsibility of the stress to the presentations and taking that away from your self.  The presentations cannot give or take away your stress, that's something only you can do and you can do it!   What language can you change in your self talk?  For example, are you saying "I can't speak in front of an audience! I'll fail?"  That sounds a lot different than "I studied my butt off and if I practice speaking out loud, I can ace this presentation!"  Although this is a short answer, I do believe that counseling will help you overcome these stressful feelings and bring out your inner confidence.
dollyAnswerText: First, identify what exactly makes you feel stressed out when you present. Being shy can make it hard for you to engage with people, so perhaps the biggest issue is that you're feeling intimidated by the audience or that you're worrying about looking stupid. Tailoring your speech to the audience--which you have control over--can help alleviate some of that stress. For example, if you are presenting to a large auditorium, you may want to consider speaking in a more conversational tone, and include facts or other examples from your research that are likely to be relevant to the audience. If you're presenting to a smaller audience, you may be worried about your audience's ability to understand you, so perhaps you should find someone else to help review your presentation for technical accuracy. You can learn new presentations techniques by watching presentations on TED or Cal Newport's amazing book 'Deep Work.'

questionTitle: I have difficulty with communication
questionText: I am a really shy person. I'm currently in a graduate program which requires lots of presentations, but they always make me feel stressed out and less confident. How can I get more confident?
therapistInfo: Krista Harper, MA, LMFTLicensed Marriage and Family Therapist in Georgia and Hawaii
answerText: First of all, way to go in stretching yourself out of your comfort zone! You are sure to grow through all of this practice presenting to your peers, and that in itself will help to grow your confidence over time. In the meantime, do whatever you can to help yourself feel prepared for each presentation. Do your work ahead of time so that you feel wellinformed on your topic, and then spend the days leading up to your presentation practicing. Do your presentation in the mirror, while you are driving (if it won't distract you from the road), and practice in front of a friend. On the day of the presentation, eat a balanced meal, get a pep talk from a supportive friend, use deep breathing to keep your body calm, and remind yourself that you are prepared. You got this!
dollyAnswerText:
Here are some ways to get more confident:
1. Get external support: Find a friend or mentor who can provide a safe space to express your thoughts and feelings. Having someone who is also very shy to practice with can help you overcome your anxiety.
2. Practice. Choose a topic that you are interested in and learn everything you can about it. Practice presenting on that topic and find a way to present awkwardly so that you can actually feel your feelings. 
3. Focus on the goal. Rather than focusing on the presentation as the end all be all, think about how you can structure the presentation so that you get a sense of achievement at the end. For example, if you have a bio exam, instead of only focusing on the paper, think about how you can study for the exam, and focus on the steps towards getting the assignment completed.

questionTitle: I have difficulty with communication
questionText: I am a really shy person. I'm currently in a graduate program which requires lots of presentations, but they always make me feel stressed out and less confident. How can I get more confident?
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Have you tried rehearsing to yourself or a trusted friend what you will present to the class?   The more confident you feel in a safe space, the more chance there will be of making the same presentation to a larger group.Giving presentations is not necessarily a difficulty with communication.   It has more to do with performance than expressing yourself clearly.Practice, practice, and practice, until you see yourself improve in how you present.Also, keep in mind that whatever anxiety you may feel about making a mistake, the audience is almost alway much more forgiving than the person who feels anxious.Anxiety heightens fear, so whatever concerns you have, check if they are growing from anxiety instead of a realistic assessment of your abilities or audience receptivity.Good luck!
dollyAnswerText:
Here are a few things that can help you to feel more confident:
- Take lots of practice tests. Confidence usually takes lots of practice to build it up.
- Learn from positive role models. Research shows that we tend to seek out information and insights from those with high self-esteem. If you're shy, seek out positive role models and learn from them.
- Get good sleep and eat well. A study by Northwestern University found that both feeling stressed and lacking sleep can reduce your self-confidence.
- Find a therapist that understands and supports your needs. Many therapists will specialize in treating shy individuals, so talk to your therapist about strategies to improve your confidence.

questionTitle: I have difficulty with communication
questionText: I am a really shy person. I'm currently in a graduate program which requires lots of presentations, but they always make me feel stressed out and less confident. How can I get more confident?
therapistInfo: Darlene ViggianoLet Your Inner Light Shine!
answerText: I can offer you hypnosis for confidence in presentations, via Skype, if you're in Cali.
dollyAnswerText: Improving your confidence is a skill that can be developed over time.  One way to improve your confidence is to prepare extensively for your presentations.  Learn your material and practice it repeatedly until you get comfortable with it.  This will help reduce nervousness before your presentations.

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: Sue BatesChange your dating & relationship patterns.
answerText: Oh, crying in therapy is very normal! I have a stack of kleenex boxes in my office. Cry away, therapist are very used to it:) First time being in therapy is scary, but you'll soon know if you are a good match.
dollyAnswerText:
Yes, this is completely normal. Therapy can be a scary experience and hearing your own thoughts and describing your emotions can be a difficult thing to do. It's perfectly normal to be worried before your first counseling appointment and to feel a fair amount of nervousness when the time comes to talk about your feelings and emotions.
Part of counseling is addressing the uncertainty that many of us feel about our emotions and thoughts, so it's natural to be a little hesitant or fearful to first time counseling patients. However, there are steps you can take to help prepare for your appointment:

- Write down questions you want to ask your therapist. A good therapist will be able to anticipate your questions, so ask your questions beforehand so you don't feel rushed during your appointment.
- Research the topic of your therapy. Make sure you are well-informed about the material. For example, if your therapist is going to be discussing a difficult topic such as a childhood trauma, do some research on the topic before your appointment to learn more. 
- Give yourself enough time to get ready for your appointment. Try to wait at least an hour before beginning any self care activities (e.t.xng, coffee, therapy, etc.) so you have time to spend getting ready

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: Miriam Dyak
answerText: People do cry in therapy sometimes, but it's not at all necessary to cry in order for most kinds of therapy to be helpful. When you start counseling you don't yet know your counselor very well, so it's normal to keep your feelings in check until you feel comfortable and a bit more relaxed with your counselor and with the situation. Sometimes, though, there are emotions that have been waiting and waiting to finally find someone who will listen with a kind ear. If you feel safe right away in the situation with your counselor, you might just cry in spite of your fears about it. Your therapist is used to people expressing how they feel and will keep strict confidentiality, so even though it's embarrassing, finally experiencing someone truly listening with empathy and kindness may just be worth it. It's okay too to let your counselor know right at the beginning that you're kind of freaked out about getting too emotional in front of another person.
dollyAnswerText: If it's something you worry about then you should be worried about it. Snooping on someone who is trying to hide their feelings is rude and will likely result in unintended pain and embarrassment for both parties. No one should be snooped on.

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: Fenny Goyal‘Sahara’ means support and that is what I will do to help you meet your potential
answerText: Crying is a natural process when you talk about upsetting things especially in therapy when you are opening up and being so vulnerable. I suggest that you consider how you would feel/respond to someone that was confiding to you and they began to cry. If you felt concerned, supportive and empathetic then you know exactly how us therapists feel when our clients are emotional in sessions. I suggest that you think of times where you have cried and how you felt at that time in public and what would have helped to make you feel less uncomfortable during your tears. I think of crying like any other natural reaction of our body such as sneezing, laughing, coughing. You can't help but do those things and most people won't really judge negatively if you do it in public. Similarly, crying is our body's reaction when we are emotional whether it is tears of joy, from a hilarious joke or from being upset. If you are very uncomfortable about crying but willing to start therapy perhaps you can ask the therapist if you can turn your chair around if you begin crying. This way you are not facing them and can self soothe without worrying about how you physically look at that time.I wish you luck and you should be proud of yourself for starting therapy and I wish you a wonderful journey on this important path that you are embarking on.
dollyAnswerText: Well, you'll be surprised that some clients can be sensitive to their emotions so having these emotions come up will likely be viewed as a strength rather than a weakness. However, if you do get emotional in front of your clients, you can imagine how uncomfortable it could be for them! I remember my first ever counseling client during my master's degree and I was so nervous that my hands were literally trembling so much I couldn't connect the headphones to the computer. Even though I completely freaked out, the reaction made me feel so much more confident about my ability to help my clients. So it's a good feeling to feel nervous, but also really good to feel embarrassed if you do get emotional in front of your clients!

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: Meg McKeon
answerText: It is not uncommon to be a bit nervous meeting your therapist (or another person) for the first time. Your therapist understands that calling and getting an appointment was a big step for you and will do their best to put you at ease. Providing a safe environment for our clients includes not judging them and being comfortable with the information and emotions that they share with us. It is ok to cry and to trust that the therapist will honor this as part of your process.
dollyAnswerText: Crying in front of my clients is a very normal part of being in therapy, and is not considered embarrassment.  If you are experiencing the stress of starting a new job, moving, or any other significant change in your personal or professional life, it is completely normal for those feelings to surface at the times when they are most intensively experienced.  If you are experiencing a lot of stress you could consider scheduling a session if you experience this stress in those few days.

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: David KleinHumanistic, LGBT-Affirmative Psychotherapy for Individuals & Couples
answerText: Yes, if crying is how you are expressing an emotion, then not only would it be normal, but hopefully encouraged, because it's an important part of therapy to have a safe space to express your emotions. We might encourage you to put words to the tears as well, to help you expand on your experience and begin to make more sense of it.As a therapist, our job is help you open up and feel comfortable enough doing so. I sincerely hope no therapist would ever shame you for whatever experience you are having in the room.
dollyAnswerText: Yes, I recommend that you take somecomfort/confidence-building actions before your first counseling/therapy session. One way to do this is to consider the following analogy: you're starting a conversation with an incredibly impressive and highly successful person. Your very good friend calls you up and invites you over to their house for dinner. When you arrive, the hostess leads you to the living room and gives you a glass of champagne. Before you have a chance to take a sip, the hostess says "Wow, you look and feel amazing. Here, let me get you some cool-weather clothes so you can go for a swim later. Oh, and we have some fantastic chicken wings sitting in the fridge that you've never had. Would you like one?" It's okay to be nervous, but here's what you can do about it: think of the person you are about to communicate with as a particularly successful and impressive person. Imagine what it would be like to have dinner with a multi-billionaire or imagine the speaker at the conference you are about to present at. I am certain that the fear of embarrassing yourself will lessen and, even if it doesn't go away entirely, at least you will have taken the first small step in building your confidence.

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: Kevin MimmsBuilding Better Connections
answerText: It is is absolutely normal to cry in therapy. I can understand wanting to keep everything together and put your best foot forward with everyone you come into contact with, but it can be such a powerful experience to cry with somebody that can hear you and accept you. It's so brave of you to go and share yourself with your counselor! I hope you will keep being brave as you begin healing.
dollyAnswerText: Yes.  In therapy, you will talk about difficult things that have happened in your life.  It is important to remember that this is a safe space for you to express your thoughts and feelings, so feel free to get emotionally open.  Do take note that at times this will be difficult for others to hear and this is a good sign.  If you have been feeling pain around a particular time in your life, or have difficulty opening up about a topic, it could be a sign of significant emotional trauma.  If this is the case, you will want to seek professional help to process your feelings, including therapy.

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: David RouttPresident and Clinical Counselor at Totius Therapies
answerText: When talking about difficult issues, it is very normal to cry. Crying is a natural way for us to cope with the sadness that we experience in life. When confronting some of these things in a counseling session, tears just seem to come naturally. Every Counselor should be well equipped to handle that level of emotion, and you would be far from the first to cry when talking with a Counselor.
dollyAnswerText: Definitely worry about it!  Crying in front of other people is the number one cause of therapists becoming burnt out, because it is so hard to keep those tears inside.  If you do end up having a breakdown in public, it's always better if you have a therapist present so they can keep you calm and help you recover as quickly as possible.  If you feel you need to cry in sessions, make sure you do so under the guidance of your therapist so you aren't stressing out all the other clients.

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: Elissa Grossclinical psychologist
answerText: Hi there !  As someone who has practiced as a clinical psychologist for 25 years , I would say that crying is NOTHING TO WORRY ABOUT AT ALL ! Almost every single person I have worked with has cried at one point or another.  Starting therapy takes a lot of courage; when you work with a therapist ,once you feel safe ,  you talk about a lot of very private and potentially emotional things that you may have never discussed with anyone before.  I have seen  people cry with sadness , cry with relief at releasing painful things they have held onto for a long time, cry because they feel so relieved that they finally feel heard.   I myself have sometimes cried with clients because some things they talk about are so profoundly moving.   I can assure you that most , if not all , therapists expect clients to cry  and there is nothing to be embarrassed about.   Crying can be very cathartic and can allow us to release a lot of painful feelings we have been stuffing down.   Crying is  often a sign that you are really working things through and getting in touch with feelings that you need to get in touch with in order to heal .So , to summarize , don't worry at all about crying! It will probably feel uncomfortable  at first , but I promise you , you will not be judged for crying in therapy.   And it will be less embarrassing once it happens a time or two and you are assured that your therapist will be there for you and won't judge you !Good luck !!
dollyAnswerText: - Crying in therapy can feel very overwhelming.  Especially when it's in front of your therapist.  It's natural to be nervous.  Some people like to start therapy by journaling about their fears.  Others like to listen to music to help them get into a rhythm.  Some people like to draw or paint while they listen to music.  Others like to take a cold shower or stand in front of a fan and just cry.  Whatever helps you start to feel more at ease.  Worries build up, it's normal and natural.  Pay attention to your emotions and try to be kind to yourself.  Let it all out eventually, everyone has cried a lot in their life.

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: Allison VelezIs your relationship worth it?
answerText: Lots of people do cry in session, but your therapist won't be uneasy with this.  Crying is a natural response and it also releases toxins, so some might say it's necessary!  Remember that you can be in charge of what you talk about in your session and if there's something that feels too uncomfortable, just say, "I'm not ready to talk about that."  Your counselor wants  you to feel at ease and will probably not push you right away to a very uncomfortable place.  As you get to know your therapist, you will feel more relaxed and even not worry so much about how you appear to them.  It's normal to be anxious going into a new situation especially when you might not feel in control of uncomfortable emotions.  Don't give up, go and put your best effort in! Hope that helps, Allison
dollyAnswerText: It's ok to worry about that! Most people don't like seeing their counselor/therapist cry, especially if it's overtly caused by personal issues. By including techniques in your session that will help you communicate to realize/address your feelings/concerns, you can minimize the chance of crying during your first session. However, if it is indeed a problem that causes your significant tears, I would recommend seeking out a second opinion before committing to therapy, as it's very common for people to start to realize that they actually need professional counseling after their first few sessions.

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: Lynn OwensChristian Counseling for Women & Couples
answerText: Many people cry during their therapy sessions. Actually most people cry in their therapist's office. I tell my clients that it's safe to cry in my office and crying isn't a sign of weakness. It's a normal human response to pain. People actually do more harm to themselves by trying not to cry than by crying. Crying is very cleansing and an important part of the healing process for many people.
dollyAnswerText: Of course it is. Many people worry about embarrassment or crying during therapy, but it's really more of a feeling of freedom and release. It's fine to feel scared or anxious about starting counseling or therapy but more important to be honest with yourself about what your real fears are and to address them. You should feel comfortable and silly enough to allow yourself to reveal your deepest secrets. Telling your deepest secrets can be very healing and is the key to truly growing as a person.

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Please feel free to cry during therapy if you suddenly feel painful emotions arising when you describe some of your unsatisfying and unfulfilling relationships and situations.Crying when realizing the emotional hurt and unfairness between you and someone, clears you for new ways of handling interactions.As a therapist, I always have a box of tissues on the table next to the couch where people who utilize my therapy, sit.I hope you will soon discover that once your tears unlock your awareness of harmful relationships in your life, you will quickly see the freedom to establish new and happier patterns of relating.Have a good therapy!
dollyAnswerText: Of course. It is completely natural and completely normal to feel nervous and excited about starting a new experience like counseling/therapy. Even in adulthood we often feel nervous and excited about experiences that are important to us. However, it is equally possible to do your best to not let this fear impact your ability to have a happy experience and simply focus on the task at hand. One of the best ways to do this is by letting your excitement motivate you, i.e., you can learn from your nervousness, and ultimately it will be a positive experience if you let it get you excited. Remember to take deep breaths, visualize a happy, positive scenario and just let yourself get to it!

questionTitle: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
questionText: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?
therapistInfo: Lola Georgwww.GeorgAssociates.com
answerText: Please do not worry about crying. People cry, laugh, rage, rant, and talk during counseling sessions. Part of the therapy process is to look at your feelings, and to feel what you are actually feeling (instead of what you think you should feel). So if you need to cry, that's ok. If you feel embarrassed because you cried, or if you feel anxious that you might cry, well those feelings are ok as well. Your counselor can help you manage your feelings so that you can attain your goals, and your counseling session is the perfect place for that.
dollyAnswerText:
No, you are not going to embarrass yourself by starting counseling/therapy. But there is a good chance you will experience one or more of the following during the first counseling/therapy session:
* Sighing or even crying, just because you're nervous and anxious.
* Giggling or smiling a lot, because these are common feelings when starting counseling/therapy.
* Looking around or making little private noises, because you're getting uncomfortable in your skin.
This can be really difficult to get used to, so be sure to ask for help if this happens.

questionTitle: I'm not sure if I have social anxiety disorder
questionText: I feel too scared to meet people I don't know - even relatives. I don't ever raise my hand or talk in school. I feel like no one understands. How can I handle this?
therapistInfo: Amy Higgs OTR/L, CLT, CAPSMobile Occupational Therapist: sensory bus for children with ASD, SPD, ADD/ADHD and trauma
answerText: Social Anxiety is scary. You don’t feel safe in relationships and prefer to isolate yourself from the outside world. Is it something you can talk to your parents about? A school counselor could help you. The counselor could possibly order an evaluation to determine how to help.Build your self confidence  Start slow with your family and identify a subject you are familiar with and add to a general conversation. It’s important to start finding things in common with others. You don’t need to carry the conversations, just add a phrase or two. Have an exit strategy if you get too uncomfortable. Keep notes of what worked and what didn’t work so you’ll be prepared for your next opportunity. Carpe Diem!
dollyAnswerText: You feel too scared to meet people you don't know? That is very normal. Even when we are young we tend to be very timid. This is normal and it will get better with age. What you should do is - take baby steps, talk to people, ask questions. Your family will understand.

questionTitle: I'm not sure if I have social anxiety disorder
questionText: I feel too scared to meet people I don't know - even relatives. I don't ever raise my hand or talk in school. I feel like no one understands. How can I handle this?
therapistInfo: Lauren Ostrowski, MA, LPC, NCC, DCC, CCTPI tailor my therapeutic approach to each client's strengths and goals
answerText: It certainly sounds like you have some anxiety. Before deciding whether it was social anxiety or a more general type of anxiety, I would wonder what it is that you think will result from you raising your hand or talking to someone you don't know. Here is some information on social anxiety: https://socialanxietyinstitute.org/whatissocialanxietyI would recommend talking to a local mental health professional. It sounds like your anxiety is affecting your daily life and there are lots of strategies that may help to lessen that.Thanks for being brave to post here.
dollyAnswerText: It is ok to speak to family members if they ask you to. It may be hard to raise your hand or talk in school but it will give you a sense of pride and accomplishment if you seek out difficult topics to talk about and do your best to contribute to the conversation. It is ok to ask others for help if you need it. It may be hard to meet new people but remember that everyone is different and it is ok to be shy at times. You can find support from your family and friends online to help you meet people in person. Don't be afraid to ask for advice and tips to help you meet and socialize. Everyone has gone through an introvert phase and something to remember is that you are not alone and you can read books like this one to help guide you through introverted moments: https://www.amazon.com/dp/1576707514/ref=cm_sw_r_s_wp_front_qKVWrRE2EX/102-6594296-3577293?ie=UTF8&qid=1534770632&sr=8-widget-m

questionTitle: I'm not sure if I have social anxiety disorder
questionText: I feel too scared to meet people I don't know - even relatives. I don't ever raise my hand or talk in school. I feel like no one understands. How can I handle this?
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Congratulations on your courage to ask this question!This shows you are willing to engage with other people, just not in all situations, especially the in person ones.Start by "meeting" yourself.Reflect as thoroughly as possible as to what you imagine will be the outcome of meeting others or of speaking up during a class.Some people are afraid of being criticized or judged by other people, or do this to themselves inwardly.  If you are judging or criticizing yourself to be less worthy of having opinions or views or of being who you are, than others, then the thought of actually placing yourself in this situation, would feel intolerable.One way to move out from this position of feeling less than others, is to recognize that these feelings are inside of you.Then it is possible to know at least on an intellectual level that it is not true that any one person is superior to another.All the people whom you are afraid to meet, also have their own insecurities.We are all equal in worth and in having blindspots about ourselves.Also, it is possible that you are naturally shy and may be expecting more from yourself than is reasonable, in terms of a standard about meeting others.You may have a few fears of being judged unfairly, you may also simply not enjoy being around people very much.Be aware to not push yourself beyond your natural limits.  Overcoming fears of being judged is different than forcing yourself to do what is against your basic nature.
dollyAnswerText: It's ok to feel shy or nervous when meeting someone you don't know. Most people find it natural to be nervous around new people so try not to feel guilty. Remember that meeting new people is part of life and you'll eventually get used to it. If you're still shy in adult life try to volunteer at a child club or youth group to meet other adults and make small talk. Also remember to talk to people you know!

questionTitle: When I'm around children I get this intense feeling of paranoia and fear
questionText: I'm a male in my early 20s. Lately, my paranoia about being around kids is causing me too breathe heavy and sweat a lot. I then start to act weird because I'm trying to fight my paranoia. This leads to people starring at me because they don't know that I'm suffering from panic attacks and paranoia. They just notice me acting scared around kids and they think I'm a threat because of it.    I'm not a pervert or predator. I would never hurt a kid. I like kids and don't know why I'm so scared to be around them.    I don't understand why I feel like this. Am I a bad person? How do I make this stop?
therapistInfo: Martin Hsia, Psy.D.OCD, Anxiety, and Insomnia Specialist
answerText: In our practice, many people we see have unwanted thoughts of doing harm to children  physically or sexually. As you said, these are intrusive and unwanted thoughts  not genuine desires to harm them. This is a form of OCD we often call Harm or Pedophilic OCD. What you are describing here as "paranoia" sounds similar to this, and is so demoralizing because you are dealing both with the distress of these unwanted thoughts and feelings, as well as the fear and uncertainty about your own character as a good person.If this is really what is going on (further assessment by the right professional would determine this), the current gold standard approach to addressing OCD is Exposure with Response Prevention  in this case, confronting the feared situations, thoughts or images on purpose, rather than avoiding them, until they lose the fear and shame associated with them.
dollyAnswerText: Hello, and thanks for writing in. I'm very sorry to hear that you are going through such a hard time at the moment. I can understand how it can be hard to not be able to control your emotions and just be upset and sad, because it's so painful to go through. I know exactly how you feel. I suffer from panic attacks too, and it can be hard to know when you are going crazy and having a panic attack. I recommend seeing a psychiatrist or a doctor that has experience in treating mental health disorders. I'd love to help you out and I'll do my best.

questionTitle: When I'm around children I get this intense feeling of paranoia and fear
questionText: I'm a male in my early 20s. Lately, my paranoia about being around kids is causing me too breathe heavy and sweat a lot. I then start to act weird because I'm trying to fight my paranoia. This leads to people starring at me because they don't know that I'm suffering from panic attacks and paranoia. They just notice me acting scared around kids and they think I'm a threat because of it.    I'm not a pervert or predator. I would never hurt a kid. I like kids and don't know why I'm so scared to be around them.    I don't understand why I feel like this. Am I a bad person? How do I make this stop?
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Your question is written in a very sincere tone.   This, together with the fact of searching for selfunderstanding, sound more like someone who is unsure and puzzled, not someone who is "bad".What was your own childhood like?The sensations you describe feeling sometimes occur in people who are reminded of very deep hurts from during their own childhood.Is it possible what you're feeling is from being reminded of great distress you lived through when you were at a similar age as the kids around whom you feel this sudden and great paranoia and fear?
dollyAnswerText: I'm very sorry that you're suffering from panic attacks and paranoia.  This sounds very stressful and I'm sure that you are trying your best to get help.  I recommend that you contact your GP for medical advice or your local mental health hospital.   You can also visit our Lifeline website and call a counsellor toll free at 1-844-488-HOPE (holmpd).

questionTitle: Do I text, call, or make contact first, the same day of the morning I left his house?
questionText: I've known him for about six years. We've dated off and on. I hadn't seen him in close to three years but recently started seeing him again. I really want this to last this time. I stayed the night. Do I text, call, or make contact first, the same day of the morning I left his house?
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: It is possible your question reflects some insecurity about whether or not either or you would like this relationship to continue.Otherwise, the answer to your question would appear naturally.  If you genuinely feel close enough to this person to sleep with him, then who texts whom first, wouldn't really matter too much.Try to understand within yourself whether you feel truly interested in this person as much as you would like to feel toward someone.
dollyAnswerText: You should text first, then call if that goes well. If you have to text several times, it's probably easier to do the first text the day after you saw him last time. If you call, it's better to wait a couple days after the call, and wait a couple days after the last text. You don't have to call the same day, but it's easier to do it the day after the last time you texted.

questionTitle: Do I text, call, or make contact first, the same day of the morning I left his house?
questionText: I've known him for about six years. We've dated off and on. I hadn't seen him in close to three years but recently started seeing him again. I really want this to last this time. I stayed the night. Do I text, call, or make contact first, the same day of the morning I left his house?
therapistInfo: Lauren Ostrowski, MA, LPC, NCC, DCC, CCTPI tailor my therapeutic approach to each client's strengths and goals
answerText: I don't see why you can't call, text, or make contact first. It would be up to him to reply when he can and wants to, but I don't know why you couldn't initiate contact.One thing to consider as you get to know each other better is having conversations about conversations. For example, you could say "I'd like to call or text you more often, but I'm concerned about _____ (listing what you are most worried about)." Then he can discuss his reaction and you can have a dialogue about it.
dollyAnswerText: I really want this to last this time, so if we're going to be texting, calling, or making contact we should do so the day after you spend the night together. If you left his house the same morning you arrived, I think the most likely contact method is by text. If you arrived later, I'd wait to contact him the same morning because it's more likely you would have talked about what happened and left things open to contact.

questionTitle: Why do I feel anxious and uncomfortable at parties or big social situations?
questionText: Example would be homecoming? I was at my high school's home football game on Friday, and I left because I felt uncomfortable with all the people there and I just wanted to be by myself. Why is that?
therapistInfo: Amelia Mora MarsHi, I'm Amelia. I help overwhelmed, stressed out teen girls and women find peace again.
answerText: Hi! I'm Amelia. Oh, that is so frustrating! Have you ever heard of social anxiety? Sounds like you may be suffering from it. Here is a link to a quiz... https://www.psycom.net/socialanxietytest/.Besides being a therapist, I am a Mom to 10 kids. A couple of my kids are very uncomfortable with crowds and become very anxious. Find yourself a therapist who can assess you and spend time with you to address these issues and to help you learn tools to help you navigate these emotions.I am wishing you the best!
dollyAnswerText: Because there were a ton of people there that I didn't know, and some of them were incredibly rude and obnoxious, I decided it was better if I left.

questionTitle: How can I be less afraid of people?
questionText: I am a female and in my early teens. I don't want to feel afraid of people. When I meet someone, I know that they are okay, but I still feel afraid.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Maybe the problem is learning to trust yourself to not be afraid other people!Reflect on what you believe would increase your trust of believing your own judgement on whom to trust.If you've had any type of violation during your growing up years or witnessed someone in your family be violated, emotionally, physically or through some terrible accident or incident, then you may hesitate to believe other people are safe and not to be feared.Give yourself plenty of time and reassurance that as long as you are making sincere effort to increase you comfort around other people, eventually you will succeed.
dollyAnswerText: I think that fear is built into our brains, as a natural response to protect us from harm. Your brain has evolved over millions of years to protect you, so that's why you can survive. Fearing  or being afraid of other human beings is natural, because most humans have harmed or will harm others. Your brain may fear an animal attack, or the fear of a parent reprimanding you. That's why you need to make yourself visible when you are meeting someone, and wear a brand that communicates your safety and trust. You can take medicines like Propranolol and Ameba that reduces your fear.

questionTitle: I want to feel more comfortable around people
questionText:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?
therapistInfo: Dr. John Frampton
answerText: There's a lot of layers there to your situation, and I'm focusing on two layers that may be contributing to your feelings of discomfort around others.  One layer is the daunting news that your son has autism.  Many parents can feel overwhelmed and distraught with this diagnosis.  The vast array of treatments available is daunting in and of itself at times to wrap one's head around.  Taking time to reflect or seek out therapy regarding how this diagnosis has impacted you may be helpful.  Some parents feel their individual identity gets lost in the diagnosis because they have dropped everything to help their child, and others may experience guilt.  If either of these or other feelings come to the forefront for you, it may be worth working through them with a therapist.  A support group list is available through www.autismspeaks.org and may help connect you with others raising children with autism.A second layer is the abusive relationship you were involved in.  The trauma you experienced in this relationship may have a very meaningful impact on your ability to trust and to be intimate with others.  Engaging with a therapist can help facilitate the healing process, as well as paving the way for more comfortable and trusting relationships.
dollyAnswerText: One way to feel more comfortable around other people is to make more time for yourself. You should spend 15-30 minutes a day doing a mind exercise to relax your brain. Find a comfortable spot and start relaxing your body by walking, stretching, moving your fingers along with a soothing music. Relax your mind by repeating a relaxing phrase like "feeling comfortable" or "life is beautiful". After you relax for some time, your brain will soon start adapting the new neural pathways and you will feel more at ease around other people.

questionTitle: I want to feel more comfortable around people
questionText:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?
therapistInfo: David KleinHumanistic, LGBT-Affirmative Psychotherapy for Individuals & Couples
answerText: It might be helpful to have a good understanding of the "why" in terms of feeling nervous around people, or the difficulty in developing more comfort. If your discomfort is somehow related to your son's diagnosis or your lack of employment, or an abusive relationship you were in and maybe embarrassed about, that is important to understand, and get clarity around. When we can understand on a deep level what is happening for us (i.e., where does fear come into this, and what's it about) we can give ourselves empathy. Everyone struggles in some aspect, so to not necessarily think of yourself as pathological is a first step. Sometimes being around people can trigger an anxiety related to being "good enough" that goes back a ways in our history. If any of the above is true, it would need acknowledgement and care from you, as opposed to shaming that experience (in the hopes it would just go away), because this experience is very real for you.
dollyAnswerText: If you are already physically and emotionally safe, one thing you can do is get close to other people. Be a listener. Don't offer your opinions all the time. Just be there to provide a safe space for others to express theirs.

questionTitle: I want to feel more comfortable around people
questionText:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?
therapistInfo: Emily ForsytheHelping clients be their most authentic selves
answerText: I'd wonder first if you were still in the same home and neighborhood where you raised your son and experienced the abuse? In many ways, we react to our environments  and if you're still surrounded by neighbors who didn't reach out when they heard your ex yelling or offer assistance and resources when your son acted differently than his peers, it might make sense that you're more timid around folks. It might also be worth thinking about where your bar is set: do you want to be as comfortable around people as you were before your recent circumstances? Or find your new normal, and connect only with people who raise you up and bolster your selfesteem? You have the right to be both cautious (if you're still surrounded by the same folks and environment) and discerning  only connecting with people who will be supportive. All the best~
dollyAnswerText: It is not easy being around other people but one of the best things you can do is to make an effort to make social activities part of your daily routine. This will help you feel more comfortable around other people. You can also make an effort to pay attention to what other people are saying. People with autism have a hard time processing social cues so it is important to pay attention to non-verbal cues to help you feel more at ease around other people.

questionTitle: I want to feel more comfortable around people
questionText:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?
therapistInfo: Jenifer FinkelsteinNCC, LPCC 44
answerText: It sounds like you have taken on a caretaker role for a while as well as experienced some pretty severe interpersonal trauma.  It makes sense that you would feel nervous around people.  Working through the trauma of an abusive relationship in itself can be a difficult process.  And then to add on the caretaker part can make things even more difficult.  First off, you may want to seek support to work through what you have experienced.  Many cities offer support with survivors of domestic violence and there is a hotline to help with this 8887247240 as well as online resources.  Processing the isolation of this relationship as well as working with your son can help to overcome the anxiety related to others.  Accessing autism support networks may be of support as well.  Other parents that will understand your experiences are a good and tend to be safer place to start in attempting to connect to others.Very importantly, go slow and be kind to yourself as you begin to adapt to a new life of allowing others to care for you as you so clearly have for others.
dollyAnswerText:
When you stop working, you will need to take care of yourself. This will include the need to develop ways to cope with stress and anxiety. Here are some simple tips to try:
1. Ask for help. Don't try to do everything yourself. Seek out help from friends or family members who are not working so that you can have someone to talk to who is not engaged in your stressful situation.
2. Develop a routine. Make an appointment for yourself each day to do something for yourself, like read a book, meditate, do yoga, etc.
3. Exercise. Taking a walk every day or doing push-ups every night can help you relax.
4. Meditate. Find a pose and calm your mind. A few minutes of mediation each day can help.

questionTitle: I want to feel more comfortable around people
questionText:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?
therapistInfo: 2nd Chance Counseling Service Online Addiction Therapy ProviderConvenient Online Addiction Therapy
answerText: I would look at  getting engaged with a support network of individuals who may also have autistic children.  They will understand some of the things that you are experiencing at home and you may also find someone who feels that same way as you. If you have not sought professional counseling for the abusive relationship I would seek out a therapist who can help you process through it so you do not repeat similar choices in your next relationship.
dollyAnswerText: I would love to get in contact with other people so that I can interact with them more. I would like to try a group activity that I was not interested in before. I would also like to volunteer at a non-profit that helps underprivileged kids.

questionTitle: I want to feel more comfortable around people
questionText:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Probably a good portion of living like a recluse was necessary so you had time to rest and recuperate from so much major adjustment in your life.Have you told some of the people in your life about the many changes you've been through?   It is possible people sense something different about you and aren't sure whether to ask or not ask questions.Also, understand what type of qualities you'd like to offer and receive in a friendship.   Given that raising a kid who has autism takes a lot of energy and time, the way you socialize will change.Start with one person whom you're pretty sure would welcome you and whom you would gain by bringing them into your life.As a result of how this interaction goes, how you decide to spend your time together, what you'll discuss, you will know more about yourself and what you require to feel good around other people.Then, you can consider if you're ready to add others into your world.
dollyAnswerText: As the abridged quote above suggests, you first need to look at your own feelings around socializing and look to see if you are being overly fearful or aggressive. Then you can look to explore practical solutions that will help you feel more at ease. For example, you can have friends over so that you feel less nervous and stay at home instead. Also, you can take an antianxiety drug like Valium. It can be overwhelming to make changes at your age so instead I suggest you explore things that you can do at home that will allow you to feel more comfortable and less anxious.

questionTitle: Do I have some type of anxiety?
questionText: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.
therapistInfo: Nicole StoneAnxiety, relationship crisis, and the separation/divorce experience.
answerText: It is possible that you could have or be developing an anxiety disorder. There isn't really enough information provided here to suggest a particular disorder, but it might be worth meeting with a counselor or therapist to do a formal assessment. Some of the questions they might ask could be what other kinds of physical symptoms you experience, how frequently these physical symptoms happen, what's going on for you when they tend to happen, and how frequently/intensely you find yourself worrying in general. Anxiety itself is a really natural thing  it's just when it starts interfering with your ability to "do life" the way you want that we start to consider potential disorders. It might be that for the most part, the anxiety you feel is normal and you simply have some triggers that intensify it more than usual. Working on your own or with the support of a counselor/therapist to both address those triggers at the root and also to develop ways of managing the actual anxiety symptoms. This twofold approach can be really helpful for not letting anxiety keep you from engaging in life the way you'd like.
dollyAnswerText: I'm so sorry you had to wait in the car. I can understand if you're feeling anxious. I've found that I'm much more comfortable in more crowded spaces when I am feeling nervous or anxious, like when I'm at a public event. Have you spoken with a therapist about this? There are so many different things that can cause your feelings of anxiety. Maybe try to shift your mindset to one of openness and see if that helps to alleviate some of your anxiety. I am always here to chat if you want to talk!

questionTitle: Do I have some type of anxiety?
questionText: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.
therapistInfo: Sitka StueveTrauma, Anxiety & Depression Management Expert
answerText: These types of symptoms can be very disruptive to life!  Anxiety often presents in two key ways:  1) physical symptoms such as: racing heart rate, sweaty palms, dry mouth, shaking or trembling or nausea  often these physical sypmtoms are categorized as a Panic Attack.  2) mentally anxiety presents itself as worry.  Worry that spirals out of control, worry that dirsupts your life and concentration.  Worry that keeps from being present in your life.  Anxiety when it begins to spiral out of control either with disruptive mental or physical symptoms, needs to be addressed formally.  I urge you to see a counselor and/or a psychiatrist soon to begin to address these issues.  Good Luck, Sitka Stueve, LSCSW
dollyAnswerText: I've noticed this too. Some days are better than others. It is common to have a low heartbeat or feel nervous before meeting people. It is natural to feel this way, and it is not a sign of anything wrong.

questionTitle: Do I have some type of anxiety?
questionText: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.
therapistInfo: Elizabeth AndersonMFT Registered Intern
answerText: Feelings of anxiety can be scary and sometimes we're not aware of the triggers that lead up to moments of anxiety, i. e., heart racing, sweaty palms, sweating, shortness of breath. It's important to realize that in moments of anxiety our body & mind are experiencing a reaction from our primal or reptilian brain that is signaling the flight or fight response within us, which kicks the hypothalamus into action flooding our body with chemicals, like adrenaline or cortisol.  So, one way to work with anxiety is to find out what the triggers are that lead to anxiety, such as fear, stress. negative thought patterns, not enough food or sleep. Keeping a daily journal can help you track the patterns and triggers and once you identify the triggers you can ameliorate them by learning new skills & techniques and by reducing stress and getting enough sleep. One quick way to reduce anxiety is by taking deeper breathes, sometimes this is called belly breathing. When you breath in make sure your belly rises and expands and as you breath out the belly deflates. Many of us do shallow breathing up in our chest which does not allow for a full breath, and getting a full breath is so important as a tool to help relax us in times of stress & anxiety .
dollyAnswerText: What I found really interesting is that, my friend, all the people who were in the store that day didn't even notice that I was late, and I felt really embarrassed. I don't know what it is, but I'm still not comfortable in large groups. Have you noticed this too? If so, do you know why it could be?

questionTitle: Do I have some type of anxiety?
questionText: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.
therapistInfo: Lorrie GuerraTransforming emotional pain in adults
answerText: I would suggest keeping a log of those days when you are having a hard time. Items to write would be what were you doing before you felt this way, did you eat and what, what time of day is it, how much sleep did you get that night, etc... This can help you identify any triggers. Further assessment can be made by a health care professional. It does sound like you are experiencing some symptoms of anxiety.
dollyAnswerText: I think your heart is racing because you're anxious. When you're anxious, it can take longer for your heart to rate the words to come out of your mouth. One way to help alleviate that anxiety is to take a deep breath and slowly count to ten. Once you have ten breaths under your belt, you can try the breathing exercise again. When you first start doing this, you might find it hard to get started. One way to get started is to breathe in for a count of four, and on the out breath, you can say the word "Calgon" out loud. Calgon Calgon Calgon. Once you start doing this, it actually works its way up your lungs, allowing more air to fill your lungs. It also helps you empty your mind of any anxieties.

questionTitle: Do I have some type of anxiety?
questionText: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.
therapistInfo: Vivian D. Echevarria Guzman, MSC, LPC-S, NCCBilingual Licensed Professional Counselor
answerText: Yes, it seems like you may have a type of anxiety: but considering that it is intermittent, it may be a good idea to talk to a therapist and explore what triggers the anxiety.  Different types of anxiety are caused by different scenarios, memories, or stressors.   Once you identify what triggers the anxiety, you may be able to identify the coping mechanism that will help you handle your symptoms.¿Tengo algún tipo de ansiedad?A veces estoy bien, puedo salir a reunirme con personas, pero otros días, mi corazón se acelera y las palabras no salen de mi boca.   Siempre pensé que era normal y que solo estaba nervioso, pero el otro día, me tomo casi 30 minutos encontrar el valor para salir del carro y entrar a Target.Si parece que tienes un tipo de ansiedad, y considerando que es intermitente, puede ser útil hablar con un consejero para explorar su causa.   Hay diferentes tupos de ansiedad que son causados por diferentes estímulos, memorias y escenarios. Ya que logres identificar que causa tu ansiedad, entonces podrás aprender mecanismos de defensa que te ayuden a controlar la ansiedad.
dollyAnswerText:
That's a really valid feeling, especially when you're going against your inclination or comfort. There could be many possible reasons why:

- maybe you had an intense conversation with someone recently, making you feel stressed or anxious
- you went out a lot recently and haven't had a chance to recover
- your body is actually preventing you from going out because of high fever or other health issues

questionTitle: Do I have some type of anxiety?
questionText: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.
therapistInfo: Karen ThackerRelationship Specialist
answerText: Though I don't know for sure, it sounds like anxiety to me. I think it would be helpful if you work with a therapist who specializes in anxiety disorders.
dollyAnswerText:
This actually sounds very similar to what is known in the field of anxiety and panic disorders as an attack. An attack can happen any time and is often accompanied by racing heart rate or shortness of breath. An attack can be especially stressful and even cause an emotional hit to your sense of well-being. This is because there is not a physical trigger present to bring on the reaction, but it's also not knowing why the reaction is occurring that can be particularly hard to cope with.

As someone who has struggled with anxiety and panic disorder for most of my life, I'm so happy that I have medication to help with my triggers and attack symptoms. Please talk to your doctor about the triggers that are a concern to you, but remember that your brain is your best ally when it comes to managing your anxiety and attack symptoms. Make sure you're getting enough rest and relaxing into the habit of turning to your brain for calmer thoughts. Make sure you're practicing breathing exercises regularly to help your body calm itself. And keep up with regular exercise, a supportive tribe, and new experiences to broaden your interests and social circles.

questionTitle: Do I have some type of anxiety?
questionText: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.
therapistInfo: Sherry Katz, LCSWCouples and Family Therapist, LCSW
answerText: Your, sitting in your car for 30 minutes, story sounds so sad and frustrating.Yes, you're describing classic symptoms of anxiety.Anxiety itself is the indirect result of repeatedly being in positions of feeling helpless or frightened.Are you able to recall from your growing up years of feeling insecure?You may not have felt loved and nurtured as much as you needed.Some people develop anxiety from missing enough love.  They feel lacking in ability to take care of themselves, similar to the lack of being sufficiently taken care of when younger.Try understanding if you felt neglected emotionally.If "yes", then start the slow process of emotionally rewarding and acknowledging yourself.Progress will be slow.Eventually you'll stabilize the way you feel toward yourself.This will gradually result in decreased anxiety.
dollyAnswerText: It has to do with anxiety. I used to be diagnosed with social anxiety, but my therapist recently added another condition that I should be grateful for. Some days, I have a hard time being social and hearing other people's opinions. Sometimes, I don't know what to say or how to react. I have noticed this especially in social situations that require me to interact with a lot of strangers, such as parties and public events. I still don't know if I am just nervous or if this is something else entirely. If I sound rude or emotionless, I am truly sorry. I will try to not be so stiff next time!

questionTitle: Do I have some type of anxiety?
questionText: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.
therapistInfo: Lauren Ostrowski, MA, LPC, NCC, DCC, CCTPI tailor my therapeutic approach to each client's strengths and goals
